repository.corpname: University of Montana, Mansfield Library, Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: Max Baucus was a Montana congressman who served in the Montana House of Representatives from 1973 to 1974, the U.S. House of Representatives from 1975 to 1978, and the U.S. Senate from 1978 to 2014, and served as the U.S. Ambassador to China from 2014 to 2016. This collection includes administrative files, constituent correspondence, sponsored and cosponsored bills, floor and hearing statements, committee files, voting records, legislative subject files, press materials, and campaign files and ephemera, as well as some personal material.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Max Sieben Baucus (born Enke) was born on December 11, 1941 at St. Peter's Hospital in Helena, Montana, to Stephen Enke and Jean Sheriff. His sister, Karen, was born two years later in Stanford, California. The Enkes separated and Jean moved with Max and Karen back to Montana. Jean married John J. Baucus Jr., a former Air Force officer, in March of 1947. Max Baucus spent the remainder of his childhood in Helena, while spending summers and weekends at the Sieben family ranch. Baucus’ first foray into public service took the shape of his participation in the American Legion Montana Boys State in 1958, where he was elected Most Outstanding Citizen. This appointment led to his nomination as one of two Montana representatives to the American Legion Boys Nation in Washington, D.C. in 1959, where he met Senators James Murray and Mike Mansfield, and Representatives Lee Metcalf and LeRoy H. Anderson. After graduating from high school in 1959, Baucus attended Carleton College in Minnesota for one year. He then transferred to Stanford University, where he graduated in 1964 with a B.A. in Economics. During his time at Stanford, Baucus spent a year traveling internationally, a trip which was to significantly shape his world view and spark a desire for a career in public service. He subsequently received an L.L.B. from Stanford University Law School in 1967.

Baucus moved to Washington, D.C. after law school, where he spent three years working as a lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission. It was there that he first met with Senator Mike Mansfield to discuss the idea of running for office. He moved to Missoula, Montana in 1971 to practice law. He was a staff member for the Montana Constitutional Convention, first as the Executive Assistant to Leo Graybill, Jr., President of the Constitutional Convention, and then as the Executive Director. Baucus was elected to the Montana House of Representatives in 1972, representing Missoula. He conducted his first Congressional campaign in 1975, beating incumbent Dick Shoup to win a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. Baucus served two terms in the House, from 1975-1978, and was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1978.

As the longest-serving U.S. Senator from Montana, Baucus served in the Senate from 1978 to 2014, winning six consecutive elections. During that time, he served nearly 10 years as Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, as well as two years as Chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee. He also served on the Senate Committee on the Judiciary, the Committee on Small Business, and the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry. Significant legislative accomplishments include amendments to the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act in 1976; tax reform efforts in the 1980s and 2000s; the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990; the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA-21) of 1998; the Rocky Mountain Front Heritage Act of 2013; securing federal recognition and support for the asbestos crisis in Libby, Montana; and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) of 2010. Baucus was a strong advocate for rural communities throughout his tenure in both the House and Senate, introducing and supporting legislation surrounding rural health care, postal service, and air service. He also worked extensively on trade issues, and was deeply involved in negotiations regarding softwood lumber imports from Canada, beef imports from Japan, and the assignation of China’s Most Favored Nation status. Locally, Baucus founded and facilitated the triennial Montana Economic Development Summit from 2000 to 2013, a jobs summit which brought together Montana residents and renowned business leaders from around the globe.

President Barack Obama nominated Baucus to the post of United States Ambassador to the People’s Republic of China on January 7, 2014. Baucus’ nomination was subsequently confirmed by the Senate on February 6, 2014, and he assumed his ambassadorial duties on March 20, 2014. He served as Ambassador until January 20, 2017. Baucus currently resides in Montana.

scopecontent.p: This collection, the Max S. Baucus Papers, represents the material sum of Max Baucus’s political career, from his work at the Montana Constitutional Convention to his appointment as the United States Ambassador to China. It includes manuscript materials, artifacts and memorabilia, microfilm, audiovisual material, photographs, and electronic records produced throughout Baucus’s time in the Montana House of Representatives, the United States House of Representatives, the Senate, and ambassadorial service. These records document policy and legislation development, constituent services, Baucus’s committee service, political campaigns, his membership in the Democratic Party, and office administration. Particularly well-represented are Senate legislative materials, as well as constituent correspondence from his time in both the House and the Senate.

The collection also includes some material from Baucus’s personal life which provides a small snapshot of his daily and social activities throughout his time in public service. This material primarily takes the form of photographs, ephemera, miscellaneous correspondence and holiday cards, invitations, and notebooks.

accessrestrict.p: Researchers must use collection in accordance with the policies of Archives and Special Collections, the Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, and The University of Montana-Missoula. All files from Max Baucus' terms in the US Senate - with the exception of press clips, press releases, speeches, floor statements, sponsored and cosponsored bills, and photographs - are fully restricted until 2044.

userestrict.p: Researchers are responsible for using in accordance with 17 U.S.C. and any other applicable statutes. Copyright was not transferred to the University of Montana. The majority of copyright is retained by Max S. Baucus, though some materials may be in the public domain.

prefercite.p: Max S. Baucus Papers, Archives and Special Collections, Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana-Missoula.

custodhist.p: Materials in this collection were transferred to the Archives by Max Baucus and various staffers, the majority of which were shipped to the Archives from storage at the Washington National Records Center in Suitland, Maryland. The transfer of some electronic records was also facilitated by the Sergeant at Arms of the United States Senate.

acqinfo.p: This collection was deposited at the University of Montana Archives and Special Collections by the creator, Max S. Baucus, in April 2014. Subsequent accessions were added to the collection in 2015, 2017 and 2018.

processinfo.p: The collection was processed between December 2014 and August 2018. Series determinations loosely followed the original organizational schema of the material, and folders within subseries are arranged in either alphabetical or chronological order. Staff files are the exception, where folders are first arranged alphabetically by staffer name and original order is maintained therein. Duplicates, case files, published works by authors other than Max Baucus, unsuccessful academy applications, job and internship applications, sampled petitions, and non-essential memorabilia have not been retained. Original folders were kept where possible, though most were disposed of due to their acidic nature; all material has been rehoused in archival-grade boxes.

Electronic records were obtained via network transfer and conversion of physical media—including external hard drives, CDs, DVDs, thumb drives, and floppy disks—and consist of both born-digital and digitized materials. These records are arranged by series, though some series do not contain electronic records. Original file names have been retained, excluding files which were not organized or described.

relatedmaterial.p: A series of oral history interviews were conducted with Max Baucus in 2017 and 2018, and are housed in the Archives and Special Collections at the Mansfield Library (OH 456).

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

controlaccess.corpname: Montana. Legislative Assembly. House of Representatives.

scopecontent.p: Materials in this series provide insight into the personal and family history of Max Baucus. They largely pertain to Baucus’s life outside of politics, though his personal and political lives inevitably overlapped as a career elected official.

arrangement.p: This series is divided into two sub-series: Personal and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries represents the physical portion of this series, and contains invitations and materials related to various social events on Capitol Hill which Baucus attended, including Presidential inaugurations and White House events. It also contains a number of appointment books and wallet diaries that provide a window into Baucus’s personal schedule, in contrast to official scheduling material produced by staffers. A nearly complete run of Baucus family Christmas cards is also included, several of which feature artwork created by Baucus’s second wife, Wanda Minge.

Correspondence found within this series is largely comprised of letters marked ‘Administration-Personal’ by office staff, though there are letters relating to specific incidents in Baucus’s life. The series also includes personal notes and notebooks kept by Baucus throughout his career, containing notes and observations taken during meetings, hearings, and other events, reflections on various topical issues, draft ideas for speeches, and campaign strategies. Many of these are undated. The series likewise contains a number of writings and publications authored by Baucus, including op-eds and two peer-reviewed papers. Also notable is a pocket Constitution given to Baucus by Senator Robert Byrd in 1995, which he carried with him throughout the remainder of his Senate career.

While largely comprised of material focusing on Baucus’s personal life, the series does contain some records relating to his family—chiefly obituaries following the death of Baucus’s stepfather, John Baucus, and correspondence between Jean Baucus and Ruth Chambers. Chambers was the sister of Max Baucus’s biological father, Stephen Enke, and the correspondence took place between Jean Baucus and Chambers following Enke’s death in 1974. The series also contains a Baucus family tree and family recipes.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains essays and op-eds authored by Baucus, as well as a 1983 New York City Marathon athlete profile sheet. Files have been renamed for clarity by the processing archivist.

arrangement.p: Essay and op-ed files are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to Max Baucus’s time in the Montana House of Representatives. It includes press files, bills which were sponsored or cosponsored by Baucus, voting records, and subject files. Subject files constitute the majority of this series, and consist of documents created and kept by Baucus and his staff during the course of their legislative work. Materials contained within subject files include correspondence, research materials, memos, notes, reports, and other related items reflecting the pertinent political and legislative issues of the time. Staffers assigned subjects according to a topical index. This index helped to organize many administrative functions, including legislative research, the tracking of constituent opinion, the compilation of Baucus’s legislative achievements, and responses to constituent concerns.

arrangement.p: Subject files are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: This series contains administrative records from Max Baucus’s time in the U.S. House of Representatives. Collectively they provide a picture of the day-to-day operations within Baucus’s Washington, D.C. and state offices, reflecting the wide array of activities which take place within Congressional offices.

arrangement.p: This series is divided into three sub-series: Administrative Files, Scheduling Materials, and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in the Administrative Files subseries and Electronic Files subseries are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials relating to trip planning, office equipment and supply purchases, parking, management of office finances, staff training and management, and administrative correspondence. Also included are successful academy appointments, administrative correspondence, and staff files generated by Baucus’s first Chief of Staff, Steve Browning, who held the position from 1975-1982.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries is comprised of schedules outlining Baucus’s daily agenda in great detail, with to-the-minute times, locations, and background information. These files reflect the busy day-to-day schedule of a member of Congress, as well as the level of work and planning required by staffers to keep office operations running smoothly.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically.

Scheduling materials, Billings, Great Falls, Conrad, Missoula
Scheduling materials, Canada and Montana trip

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains scanned versions of office administration correspondence from Baucus’s second term in the U.S. House of Representatives, largely centering on event scheduling, White House tours, and thank-you notes. These files were originally labeled incorrectly as memos and located elsewhere in the collection, and have since been concentrated in one folder. Original file names have been retained.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series contains press files from Max Baucus’s time in the U.S. House of Representatives.

arrangement.p: The series is divided into four sub-series: Press Materials, Press Clips and Press Releases, Speeches, and Electronic Files.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains advertising circulars, documents from radio appearances and talks, and grant announcements.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains press clips and official press releases.

arrangement.p: Each grouping is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains public remarks and addresses given by Max Baucus while serving as a U.S. Representative. In the case of untitled speeches, file names describe the event or group to which Baucus spoke.

arrangement.p: Speeches are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains press clips and speeches. While it is likely that the majority of these files are reflected in the manuscript portion of this series, exact correlations have not been fully established. The following files constitute only a portion of the files contained within this subseries. A full list of files is available upon request.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically within each category, and speech files have been renamed for increased accessibility.

did.unittitle: U.S. House of Representatives: Constituent Correspondence

scopecontent.p: This series contains constituent correspondence sent to Max Baucus during his time in the U.S. House of Representatives. Reflecting a variety of topical and legislative issues of the day, these letters provide a broad overview of Montanans’ concerns in mid- to late 1970s America. Environment and agriculture were two primary topics of correspondence, with many letters focusing on grazing, agricultural subsidies, proposed legislation, and wilderness. Central to environmental issues at the time was the passage of the Montana Wilderness Study Act (S. 393), introduced by Senator Lee Metcalf, which became law in 1977 and was to have profound effects on Montana’s land and its residents. Other common areas of concern included Panama Canal negotiations, postal matters, the Equal Rights Amendment, gun control, labor-related legislation, and the Milwaukee Railroad bankruptcy. The majority of files are arranged alphabetically by subject, which were assigned in accordance with an indexing system utilized in Baucus’s office to organize, code and track constituent mail and other documents. This series does not contain a name file.

Also contained within this series are form letters, mass mailings, and yellow files. Form letters were drafted by staffers in response to issues which generated large quantities of constituent mail—these summarized Baucus’s position and eliminated the need to create a unique response for each constituent. Mass mailings are mailings, often in the form of newsletters, sent to constituents on a regular or semi-regular basis. These provided updates on pending legislation, Baucus’s legislative and political activities, information on upcoming events, and sometimes included questionnaires and surveys. Yellow files consist of responses to constituents printed on yellow carbon paper, which are arranged alphabetically by constituent last name. This series also includes 9 reels of microfilm, containing scans of constituent correspondence from 1976.

arrangement.p: Materials in this series are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.p: This series contains legislative materials relating to Max Baucus’s time in the U.S. House of Representatives, which present a clear view of the legislative process from start to finish. These files outline the scope and extent of Baucus’s legislative work throughout his first two terms in Congress, generated and gathered by both Baucus and his staffers. Such work included policy research and development, correspondence and collaboration with members of Congress and other stakeholders, Committee hearings and deliberations, gathering and collating data, and drafting and editing legislation.

arrangement.p: The series is divided into six subseries: Sponsored/Cosponsored Bills, Floor Statements, Congressional Profile, Committee Files, Subject Files, and Electronic Files.

scopecontent.p: This subseries includes bills and resolutions which Baucus sponsored or co-sponsored.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged first by Congress, and then by bill and resolution number.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains floor statements, prepared remarks delivered by Baucus on the House floor.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains material profiling Baucus’s collaborative and individual legislative work and viewpoints. It contains legislative correspondence, typically consisting of correspondence between Baucus and other members of Congress intended to generate support for or opposition to legislation, initiatives, and issues. VIP correspondence—correspondence with well-known or prominent figures—is also included, as well as correspondence with the standing U.S. President. Also included are hearing statements, prepared remarks delivered by Baucus in Committee hearings, and voting records from the 94th and 95th Congresses.

arrangement.p: Each grouping of like material is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials generated by Baucus’s Committee service during his time in the House of Representatives. Baucus served on the House Committee on Appropriations for the entirety of his two terms in the House, and the majority of materials contained within this subseries relate to Committee work undertaken by Baucus and his staffers relating to investigations, hearings, legislation, nominations, and other projects. Also included in this subseries are committee assignment materials and files relating to the Committee for a More Active and Effective Congress, a liberal political action committee founded by Eleanor Roosevelt.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries is comprised of records which outline all aspects of legislative research, development, and implementation. File types include, but are not limited to, memos, correspondence, reports, publications, legal briefs, invitations, and legislative drafts. Subject files give a clear indication of the predominant issues which directed Baucus and his staffers’ work. Rural issues—particularly post offices and rural health—ranked high on the list, in addition to President Carter’s zero-based budgeting mechanism for government planning.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains scanned Dear Colleague letters, floor statements, hearing statements, and memos. The analog versions of these documents, along with many other types of documents produced by Baucus’s office, were scanned by staffers and converted to digital formats for storage in the office’s document management system, OnBase. Many OnBase files were duplicated or scattered during the transfer process from Baucus’s office to the University of Montana, and the majority of the files in this subseries have subsequently been rearranged by category and renamed to clarify their content, due to a lack of adequate original description. Dear Colleague letters and memos files reflect only a small portion of their analog counterparts, whereas floor and hearing statements files represent a near-complete replication of their analog counterparts. While it is likely that many of the files in this subseries are reflected in the manuscript portion of this series, exact correlations have not been fully established.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically within each category.

scopecontent.p: This series contains administrative records from Max Baucus’s time in the U.S. Senate, relating specifically to Washington, D.C. and district office operations. Such records reveal the wide range of activities that regularly occur in a Congressional office, particularly those related to legislative research, scheduling, and handling the large volume of constituent mail. They also point to the high turnover of legislative staffers and the fast pace of legislative activity, as well as the subsequent need for detailed training materials and a high level of communication.

arrangement.p: This series is comprised of three subseries: Administrative Files, Scheduling Materials, and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials reflecting the administrative capacity of a congressional office, and include a number of academy appointments, requests for appointment to military service academies that were ultimately successful. These files are not exhaustive; records of academy appointees are maintained by the academies themselves. Also contained within this subseries are a run of ‘Thank you Good Letters’, letters sent to Max Baucus expressing appreciation for speaking engagements, constituent assistance, support of various issues, and other services provided. Such letters were identified and retained by staffers for campaign and legislative record purposes. Friendly File cards likewise record constituents willing—or potentially willing—to assist in fundraising, canvassing, volunteering, and other supportive efforts. Additional administrative files include mail reports, indexes and filing keys, conference-planning materials, memos, invitations, staff training manuals and guides, and trip files. In addition to scheduling materials, trip files contain a myriad of documents including memos, background information on people and places, and drafts of prepared remarks. Of particular note in this subseries are those records pertaining to the Montana Economic Development Summit, a recurring event focusing on Montana jobs and the economy established by Max Baucus in 2000.

arrangement.p: Files are in alphabetical order.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries, while similarly reflecting the administrative functions of a Congressional office, is comprised of schedules and related documents which outline Baucus’s daily agendas. These documents provide great insight into the day-to-day activities of a member of Congress, as well as the high level of planning and meticulous attention to detail required by staffers to plan activities and maintain adherence to scheduled activities. They include specific times, locations, transportation information, background information on both issues and people, and other useful contextual information.

arrangement.p: Scheduling materials are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains born-digital administrative records from Baucus’s time in the Senate, records which were created in an electronic format. These files act as a foil to analog administrative records, serving as the digital footprint of administrative functions within Baucus’s office. In addition to such day-to-day administrative material as calendars, forms, call reports, and manuals, this subseries also contains indexes of paper records sent to National Records Centers in Denver, Colorado and Suitland, Maryland for preservation. Also included are inventories of records which were created in preparation for their shipment to the University of Montana.

Files from Baucus’s Senate website, www.baucus.senate.gov, have not been retained. Archived iterations of the website between October 13, 1999 and April 4, 2014 can be found on the Internet Archive’s WayBack Machine at https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.baucus.senate.gov/.

arrangement.p: Original order has been retained, as well as original file and folder names. Folders which contain indexes are the exception, and have been renamed to better reflect their contents.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series contains press materials produced during Max Baucus’s time in the U.S. Senate, providing insights into his communication style, public persona, and representation in local and national press. They also reveal the ways in which Baucus connected with his constituents, highlighting prioritized topical issues and demographics.

arrangement.p: The series is divided into five subseries: Press Clips, Press Releases, Speeches, Miscellaneous, and Electronic Files.

scopecontent.p: Staffers regularly collected news clippings that mentioned or featured Max Baucus, and those contained within this subseries document the entirety of his career in the Senate. Scattered throughout are Max Baucus Reports, short legislative updates and topical pieces that were written by Baucus and published in various Montana newspapers between 1979 and 1984.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of prepared statements released by Max Baucus regarding legislation, current events, sponsored and cosponsored bills, and other political and legislative issues of the day. It also contains news headlines and summaries from Montana newspapers, which were filed with some early office press releases. Beginning in March of 1993 press releases were filed individually, with topics typed on individual folder labels. While press releases are listed here by date, a list of these topics is available upon request.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: It is possible to trace Max Baucus’s growing national exposure and expertise on particular topics through this complete run of speeches and public remarks given during his time in the Senate. Baucus gave speeches to some groups on a regular basis, casting light on one of the ways in which he maintained connections with important components of his base. These included groups and events like the Montana Graingrowers Association, the AFL-CIO, the Montana Cattlemen’s Association, the Wool Growers Convention, the Montana Democratic Party Mansfield-Metcalf Dinner, and high school and college commencements. We can also trace his growing proficiency in Asian foreign affairs through the many speeches relating to Vietnam, Korea, Japan, and especially China, focusing particularly on trade, economic and human rights issues. For those speeches which are untitled, file names describe the group(s) to which Baucus spoke.

arrangement.p: Speeches are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains preparatory and administrative press-related materials, which include memos, interview preparations, and an indexed directory to important speeches.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains press clips, press releases, and speeches spanning Baucus’s Senate career. Speeches and some press releases have been renamed to clarify file content. While it is likely that the majority of these files are reflected in the manuscript portion of this series, exact correlations have not been fully established. The following speech files constitute only a portion of the files contained within this subseries. A full list of files is available upon request.

arrangement.p: Files have been arranged in chronological order within each category.

accessrestrict.p: One file in this subseries is restricted until 2044 due to privacy concerns.

scopecontent.p: This series contains constituent correspondence generated and received throughout Max Baucus’s time in the U.S. Senate. Consisting of correspondence generated by constituents, staffers, and Baucus himself, the material in this series weaves a 35-year narrative of constituent concerns, pressing topical issues, support for and opposition to legislation, and, more broadly, the symbiotic relationship between Senator Baucus and his constituents.

arrangement.p: The series is divided into four subseries: Constituent Correspondence, Petitions, Microfilm, and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Constituent Correspondence contains correspondence between Montana constituents and Max Baucus’s offices. Congressional offices undergo high staff turnover, resulting in ever-evolving records management systems and organizational schema. These evolutions are commonly reflected in constituent correspondence management, given the large volume of material, and are also affected by changes in technology. Such was the case in Baucus’s Congressional offices, particularly with the advent of in-house Senate computing technology in the mid-1980s. Constituent correspondence organizational schemas have thus been pieced together from office manuals, filing guides and computer code lists. This subseries does not contain a name file.

Several unique categories of correspondence can be found in the first fifteen boxes: ‘Dear Montana’, Form Letters, Mass Mailings, and Robo Letters. There is no clear distinction between ‘Dear Montana’ correspondence and other constituent correspondence. Form Letters consist of letters drafted by staffers in response to issues which had generated large quantities of constituent mail, summarizing Baucus’s position and eliminating the need to craft a unique response to each constituent. Similarly, Mass Mailings are mailings--often in the form of newsletters--sent to constituents on a regular or semi-regular basis. These provided updates on pending legislation, Baucus’s legislative and political activities, information on upcoming events, and sometimes included questionnaires and surveys. All of these groupings are arranged chronologically, with the exception of Robo Letters. Robo letters, which date from 1980-1985, are letters generated by an early word-processing machine known as the “ROBO” system. They consist of carbon copy letters sent from Baucus to constituents, responding to inquiries and concerns. Robo Letters from 1980 are arranged in alphabetical order by constituent last name; letters from 1981-1985 are arranged chronologically.

As is evident in the folder titles, in-office methods of filing constituent correspondence changed over the years. From 1979-1987, correspondence is arranged by topics designated by an in-house filing guide and computer code list. From 1987 through 1998, correspondence is arranged by unique numerical identifiers assigned to each letter as it was entered into the office’s Constituent Services System (CSS). These numbers do not necessarily connote, however, exact chronological order, and the dates assigned to these folders often correspond to the date on which correspondence was entered into the CSS, rather than the date on which a letter was written.

arrangement.p: From September 1998 to 2003 correspondence is arranged chronologically by date, with most folders indicating the topic of the letters held within. Correspondence is comparatively sparse between the years of 2003 and 2014, likely due to the lack of transmission of these records to the archives, and is generally miscellaneous. A separate group of correspondence is arranged alphabetically by topic, which correlate to the in-house filing guide and computer code list. In this grouping, folders are arranged in chronological order within each topic.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: The second subseries, Petitions, contains mass mailings sent to Max Baucus between 2010 and 2014. These petitions center on a number of legislative and topical issues and were mailed by constituents to convey collective grievances, opinions, and support for/opposition to particular pieces of legislation. Petitions have been sampled to reduce volume—original quantities and sampling data are available upon request.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: The third subseries consists of 799 individual reels of microfilm, containing filmed images of constituent correspondence and mail reports generated between 1979 and 1988. Please ask the archivist for a list of individual reel contents.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of electronic files related to constituent services, including e-newsletters, mass mailings, scanned correspondence and microfilm, and a smattering of in-office mail reports exported from Microsoft Outlook dating from 2011-2013. While much of the scanned correspondence does likely have analog surrogates, it is not wholly representative of analog constituent correspondence held within the Max S. Baucus Papers. Similarly, the microfilm files in this subseries correspond to a portion of physical microfilm reels, but not all. This subseries also contains data files exported from Constituent Services Systems (CSS), large-scale databases that manage the relationship between a member of Congress and their constituency. These systems facilitated a variety of activities related to constituent relations, including scheduling, correspondence and casework management, and document management. Baucus’s offices utilized a proprietary program called Intranet Quorum (IQ) from the mid-1990s to 2008, and VOICE from 2008 to 2014.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to Max Baucus’s legislative work in the U.S. Senate, encompassing policy research and development, legislation sponsorship and co-sponsorship, Senate votes, correspondence on legislative matters, and committee work. It provides a comprehensive overview of Baucus’s voting habits, relationships with his colleagues in Congress and other significant stakeholders, legislative priorities, and leadership roles in the Senate.

arrangement.p: The series is divided into nine subseries: Sponsored and Cosponsored Bills, Floor Statements, Congressional Profile, Voting Record, Committee Files, Subject Files, Libby Files, Staff Files, and Electronic Files.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the text of bills and resolutions sponsored or cosponsored by Baucus, and do not constitute a complete run. All sponsored and cosponsored bills can be found online at the U.S. Congress’ website. Legislative Activities are federal compendiums of all sponsored and cosponsored bills but include summaries of the bills rather than the full text.

arrangement.p: Sponsored and cosponsored bills and Legislative Activities are each arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: P.L. 111-148, The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains floor statements, remarks given by Baucus on the Senate floor. While floor statements are listed here by Congress, they are also foldered individually by statement topic. Please ask an archivist for an inventoried list of individual floor statement topics.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: The Congressional Profile contains material which, as the title implies, outlines the scope and nature of Baucus’s legislative work while serving in the Senate. It includes hearing statements, “Dear Colleague” and other legislative correspondence, briefing books, and legislative strategy materials. “Dear Colleague” correspondence traditionally consists of letters sent to and from other members of Congress requesting support for or against legislation, explaining policy stances, or urging other legislative actions. The “Dear Colleague” correspondence in this collection does consist primarily of such letters, though this category also contains other, less formalized correspondence between members of Congress, including handwritten and signed notes and letters on official letterhead. “Dear Official/VIP” is a Baucus office designation, applied to correspondence to and from federal officials, ambassadors, executives, and other designated important administrators. “Dear President” letters consist of letters sent from Baucus, and sometimes colleagues, to the sitting president requesting support or urging specific action on executive matters.

Legislative Strategy material contains files laying out legislative plans and strategies for upcoming Congresses, legislation, or issues. Briefing books are materials gathered by staffers to prepare Max Baucus for various trips, public appearances, hearings, meetings, and other events. They contain background information regarding people he would be meeting or speaking with, pieces of legislation, companies and cities, answers to tough questions he might encounter, and any other necessary preparatory material.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically within each category.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Voting records were produced by four distinct entities: the Congressional Research Service, the Democratic Policy Committee, various interest groups, and Baucus’s office itself. While no one grouping contains a complete run of Baucus’s Senate voting record, together they provide a comprehensive overview of his voting habits and record. Whereas materials produced by both the Congressional Research Service and the Democratic Policy Committee provide a fairly straightforward, quantitative record of Baucus’s Senate votes, those generated by interest groups and Baucus staffers tend to be more interpretative. Interest group voting records examined how Baucus voted in regards to particular issues, and were often a good gauge of support in various topical areas. Some voting records produced by Baucus staffers also focused on particular issues, though they served a variety of other purposes: tracking Baucus’s support (via votes) of particular constituencies, bolstering campaign claims, and analyzing his overall legislative record for future planning purposes. The most recent document was authored in 2018 by a former staff member, Spencer Gray, and provides a comprehensive summary of Baucus’s legislative accomplishments.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by category, and chronologically therein.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Baucus’s service on various congressional committees and subcommittees during his time in the Senate is the basis for the third subseries, Committee Files. While official congressional committee records must remain in the care of the committee itself, the congressional office records contained within this subseries were generated during work undertaken by Baucus and his staffers relating to committee investigations, hearings, legislation, nominations, and other projects. Significant within this subseries are committee records generated during Baucus’s tenure as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance, in addition to Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works records regarding the asbestos environmental disaster in Libby, Montana. Baucus served as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance on three separate occasions: January 3, 2001-January 20, 2001; June 6, 2001-November 22, 2002; and January 4, 2007-February 6, 2014. He also served as Chairman of the Committee on Environment and Public Works from January 3, 1993-December 1, 1994.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically within each committee.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Subject files consist of materials generated by Baucus and his staffers during the course of legislative and administrative work. These records, filed by subject, present perhaps the clearest view of legislative work in Congress, outlining all aspects of legislative research, development and implementation. They also illuminate the complex web of relations on Capitol Hill, outlining the ways in which Baucus and his staff worked together as well as with other members of Congress, Congressional staffers, federal employees, public officials, and constituents. Given the level of detailed description and arrangement, this subseries serves as a useful tool with which to both trace trending topical issues of the day and determine legislative priorities for Baucus and his staffers. Trade, agricultural, and environmental issues are consistently significant, as are postal services and rural health. File types include, but are not limited to, memos, correspondence, reports, publications, legal briefs, invitations, white papers, and legislative drafts.

arrangement.p: These materials are arranged first by Congressional session, then alphabetically.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Libby files are comprised of materials pertaining to the asbestos-based environmental disaster which came to light in Libby, Montana in the late 1990s. Max Baucus was instrumental in advocating for the rights of Libby citizens affected by the asbestos crisis, and pushed for the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to declare a Public Health Emergency in Libby, the first time that the agency ever did so. He also cosponsored several pieces of legislation related to asbestos injury compensation and environmental cleanup. This subseries includes material related to this legislation as well as the 2005 Department of Justice criminal proceedings against W.R. Grace and Company, W.R. Grace’s 2007 bankruptcy proceedings, asbestos litigation reform, the EPA investigation, Libby’s Superfund designation, and asbestos-related health programs and initiatives.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Documents generated by staffers in the course of their work as legislative assistants, legislative correspondents, mailroom specialists, and other legislative and administrative roles in Max Baucus’s offices constitute the eighth subseries, Staff Files. These materials focus primarily on particular topical subjects and legislation, correlating with staffers’ area(s) of expertise. While most materials were generated in the course of a singular staffer’s work, some were created by multiple staffers as indicated by initial inventories accompanying the files.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by staff name, and subsequently in original order. Original file names have been retained.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of electronic records documenting all aspects of legislative work conducted by Max Baucus and his staffers throughout his time in the Senate. It contains briefing books, unofficial committee files, floor statements, hearing statements, legislative correspondence, memos, and a small selection of sponsored and cosponsored bills, staff files, and subject files. Of particular note are Senate Committee on Finance materials, as Baucus was Chairman and/or ranking member for 12 of the 35 total years he served on the Committee. These materials consist of Finance Chairman letters, press clips, press releases, and hearing statements. Files also include hearing statements from Baucus’s other committee work, memos, subject files, voting record materials, and a number of staff files. Some files and folders have been renamed to better reflect their contents. While it is likely that many of these files are reflected in the manuscript portion of this series, exact correlations have not been fully established.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044, with the exception of floor statements and sponsored and cosponsored bills.

scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to Max Baucus’s political campaigns, shining a light on the complexity of Congressional campaign and polling activities.

arrangement.p: It is divided into five subseries: Montana House of Representatives, U.S. House of Representatives, Senate, Audiovisual, and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: These files were generated during Max Baucus’s first campaign for public office in 1972, when he ran for a seat in the Montana House of Representatives. They contain candidate statements and press materials, in addition to some campaign ephemera.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries is comprised of materials from Max Baucus’s two House campaigns in 1974 and 1976, as well as files on campaign opponents and other candidates. Files include campaign press materials, circulars and brochures, correspondence and memos.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Materials from Max Baucus’s six campaigns for election to the Senate constitute the third subseries. The groundwork for Baucus’s political campaigns was often laid two years in advance, and involved a great number of campaign staff, volunteers, canvassers, fundraisers, and political consultants. Files include campaign press materials, circulars and brochures, memos, debate preparatory materials, voter surveys and polls, endorsements, election results, and campaign ephemera.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged in chronological order, with ephemera listed last.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: Materials in this subseries consist of audio and video recordings documenting Baucus’s House and Senate campaigns. Contents include campaign advertisements, radio spots, interviews, inauguration activities, campaign events, and debates. A great deal of the magnetic tape and film reels have little to no accompanying description, and largely appear to contain short audio and video clips recorded for use in campaign advertisements. Particularly noteworthy in this subseries are Baucus family videos from 1955, presumably utilized for campaign ads.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged in chronological order.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains results from Max Baucus’s 2000 campaign primaries, as well as campaign files from Max Baucus’s Senate run in 2002, his fifth Senatorial campaign. These files include campaign media files, website material, fliers, the opening statement for a July 2002 debate with opponents Mike Taylor, Stan Jones, and Bob Kelleher, and notes from Taylor’s withdrawal press conference on October 10, 2002. Some files have been renamed to better reflect their contents.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series consist of materials documenting Max Baucus’s participation in local and national political initiatives, largely based around his membership in the Democratic Party. Files relate to Baucus’s earliest participation in the political process—the 1972 Montana Constitutional Convention—as well as his involvement in various Democratic Party groups and activities, including the Democratic Policy Committee and the Democratic Study Group.

arrangement.p: The series is divided into two subseries, Political and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries represents the physical portion of this series, and contains records relating to Baucus’s participation in local and national political processes.

arrangement.p: Materials in this subseries are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a 1972 press clip quoting Max Baucus while he was serving in the Montana Constitutional Convention. It also contains a number of topical “Talking Points” broadsides disseminated by the Democratic Policy Committee on April 10, 2003.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series contains photographic material documenting both Max Baucus’s personal life and political career.This series contains photographic material documenting both Max Baucus’s personal life and political career.

arrangement.p: It is divided into five subseries: Photographs, Accession 2017-042, Accession 2018-043, Photographic Negatives, and Electronic Files.

scopecontent.p: This subseries is comprised of physical photographs and slides spanning the entirety of Max Baucus’s political career, in addition to some family and personal photographs. These images document all aspects of Baucus’s tenure as an elected official, including legislative work, campaign activities, administrative duties, Democratic Party events, and public appearances. Many titles encompass multiple images, generally because multiple photographs were taken at a single event or because numerous photographs were taken on a single day. Original Baucus staff-generated titles have been retained.

arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged chronologically by year.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains miscellaneous photographs included in a new accession (group of materials transferred to the repository at a single time) which were transferred to the repository in 2017. These photographs largely document Baucus’s personal life and cover a wide span of time, ranging from his college days to the 2008 Mansfield-Metcalf Dinner. Photographs were assigned unique identifiers by the processing archivist.

arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries similarly contains a number of photographs included in a new accession from 2018. It consists of images from various campaign and workday events, showing Baucus interacting and speaking with people who are likely constituents. Little descriptive information accompanied these photographs, and most are undated. Photographs were assigned unique identifiers by the processing archivist.

arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged numerically by unique identifier.

scopecontent.p: Photographic negatives span Baucus’s personal and political lives, each bearing a unique numerical identifier assigned by Baucus staffers. While there is no documentation directly linking these negatives to analog surrogates in this series, it is highly likely that the majority of them do correlate with photographs in Subseries 1.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of digital images documenting Baucus’s personal and political lives, many of which correspond with analog photographs contained within Subseries 1. While it is likely that the majority of these files are reflected in the manuscript portion of this series, exact correlations have not been fully established.

Materials in this sub-subseries consist of digital images from Baucus's tenure in the U.S. House of Representatives. These photographs were digitized by Baucus staffers prior to their transfer to the University of Montana. Original file and folder names have been retained.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by file format in chronological order.

scopecontent.p: This sub-subseries contains digital images taken and compiled by both Baucus staffers and Senate staffers throughout the duration of Baucus’s tenure in the U.S. Senate. Photos taken prior to Baucus’s Senate career were gathered and used by Baucus staffers for various campaign and web content purposes. Original file and folder names have been retained. The digital images that are listed constitute only a small selection of the files contained within this sub-subseries. A complete list of files is available upon request.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically within the “Baucus Photos from Senate Photograph Studio” and “Baucus Photos from Office Collections” folders. These groupings are not necessarily indicative of the photographers, as pictures were taken by both official Senate photographers and staff members dependent on scheduling, availability and cost.

scopecontent.p: Materials in this sub-subseries consist of photographs transferred to the repository in 2018 on optical media. These images were subsequently converted to a digital format by the processing archivist. They document a 2011 hike in Big Sky, Montana, a CODEL (Congressional Delegation) trip to Iraq in 2007, and trade trips to the United Arab Emirates and Vietnam in 2008. Original file and folder names have been retained.

This series consists of audiovisual material, both audio and video recordings. It covers the entirety of Baucus’s congressional career, particularly emphasizing campaign material, television appearances, and Committee hearings, and reflects more than three decades of continually-evolving audiovisual technology.

arrangement.p: It is divided into three subseries: Audio Recordings, Video Recordings, and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains audio recordings which document field hearings, speeches, town hall meetings, interviews, news clips, campaign appearances, floor statements, and committee hearings in which Baucus took part. Topics range widely, and many of the audio recordings were recorded in towns in and around Montana. Campaign audio in this subseries is not limited to Max Baucus’s campaigns, and also covers the campaigns of some political opponents and allies, including Pat Williams and Allen Kolstad. Most, but not all, audio recordings include Baucus—some were generated during town hall meetings and field hearings at which Baucus was not present. All audiocassettes in this subseries were digitized by Baucus’s office, files which can be found in Subseries 3, Electronic Files.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains video recordings consisting of a variety of formats. Content includes committee hearings (including Environment and Public Works, Appropriations, Finance, and Agriculture), floor and hearing statements, speeches, interviews, public service announcements, town halls, news clips and talk show appearances, and campaign debates, ads, and statements. A variety of topics are covered, including foreign relations with Japan, Cambodia, and the Middle East, transportation, wilderness, tax reform, trade, and the asbestos crisis in Libby. Items with a VHS number have accompanying CD or DVD surrogates and were converted to digital files by Baucus staffers, which can be found in Subseries 3, Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains digital audio and video recordings generated throughout Baucus’s political career. The majority of these recordings were converted from analog to digital formats by Baucus staffers, and consist of campaign advertisements, television debates, television and radio interviews, public service announcements, televised floor statements, and advertisements for events like the Montana Economic Development Summit and the Faith Community Impact Summit. Converted Optical Media consists of optical media items (CDs and DVDs) which were converted to more stable digital formats by archives staff, and an inventory of their contents is available upon request. The majority of original file and folder names have been retained, though some files have been renamed for clarity. While it is likely that many of these files are reflected in the analog portion of this series, exact correlations have not been fully established.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series contains a wide variety of awards and other memorabilia given to Baucus in recognition of his legislative and public service work. Items include framed workday photographs, ceremonial pens commemorating the signing of legislation, framed pieces of legislation, various awards and certificates reflecting Baucus’s lengthy running career, miscellaneous artworks, and campaign ephemera.

arrangement.p: The series is divided into two subseries: Artifacts and Electronic Files.

accessrestrict.p: This series is restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the physical artifacts which make up the analog portion of this series. Items within the original accession (acquisition) were surveyed, and selected artifacts were retained based on their historic, intrinsic, exhibit, and/or research value.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains digital images of all awards originally contained within the Baucus Papers, including artifacts which were not retained. Original file names have been retained.

arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.p: All materials in this sub-series are restricted until 2044.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of digital records from Max Baucus's tenure as the United States Ambassador to the People's Republic of China. They include nomination endorsements from Montana leaders, Baucus's nomination statement to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, photographs from his swearing-in ceremony, a video of Baucus encouraging Chinese companies to do business in the United States, and photographs from his time spent in China as Ambassador.

accessrestrict.p: Materials in this series, with the exception of photographs, are restricted until 2044.
